comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Tycor Road today.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Perfect, thanks! Wonder if it was a biggish house that's not showing on the OSI.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: There doesn't appear to have been much in Tycor (or Ticor as it was spelt on the OSI maps back then) when this photo was taken. The nearest big house would probably have been the Manor of St. John in Lisduggan. This is Tycor on the 25" OSI map maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,658965,611881,6,9

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: There does not appear to have been any Powers living in Tycor around this time, I wonder if this was taken at Mrs Powers parents house, if so it might possibly have been at the home of Walter and Ellen Hearne. Walter was a caretaker at the waterworks in Tycor and was 72 in 1911. The house in the photo looks more like a small cottage and the kind of place a caretaker might live, bit of a wild guess I know:) 1911 Census for Walter Hearne www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003503919/

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here's what you get if you type Tycor house Waterford into google. That house is not on the 25" map, surveyed June 1905.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: But it should be! Here it is in Buildings of Ireland, with a date of c1870! Here is a Streetview of this Tycor House today, but it doesn't look like the house in the photo. I'm sure I see eaves, meaning that the one in the photo is at least partly 1 storey, while Tycor House seems to have always been 2. So, it is some smaller house in Tycor/Ticor.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Houses in Tycor 1911 Census, www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Waterford/Water... the only family named who might have lived in a house like Tycor House would have been the well known family of Widger.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Could this be them, at Yellow Road Upper? Richard Power.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: 1894 Waterford Directory 37 to 40 The Mall, Imperial Hotel, Mrs. K. Murray, proprietress 1901 census William A MURRAY, 35, Hotel Proprietor, not married Kathleen A POWER, 38, Hotel Manageress, not married 1911 census William Augustine MURRAY, 45, Hotel Proprietor, single Kathleen Agnes TOWER, 48, Manageress, single (Should be POWER. The P is the same as in Pantry woman further down the page)

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The east corner of the house appears to have a single storey annex of some sort. This may be the roof we can see in this picture.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It could equally be Rathfadden Lodge, of course. It seems to be a secret what that looks like. Neither streetview or an image search brings up anything.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley/] I doubt it Neil number 30 Upper Yellow road seems a little far away and the ages don't seem right to me. Tycor House and Rathfadden Lodge are not technically in Tycor either. I wonder if Tycor house was called that back then. In regards to my earlier comment I do think the building is a cottage and not any substantial house, there is still a caretakers cottage at the waterworks although it doesn't look exactly like the one in the photo, its got a porch which could have been added, but the height of the eaves looks pretty similar. Tycor waterworks

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I'm fairly sure the bit of buliding visible above is a wing or annex of some larger building - you can see some more of it above the leftmost gentleman's (LMG) boater. It also has a fairly tidy big-housesque garden - the hedge behind LMG's shoulder, the flat gravel drive.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02/] The note you added regarding the porch is actually where the raised plasterwork(quoins) is on the corner of the building, you can make it out on the full size image, its visible on the streetview and now painted a dark colour, I'm even more convinced now that this is the same cottage. This is something similar on a modern house flic.kr/p/5xXQ27

comment.author: 24861755@N08
comment._content: Wonderful portrait very nice to see.
comment.authorname: Christine Rose.., Huge Thanks To All My Flick'r Fr

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] There's just one bit of the mystery still to complete, then. Is that a hedge or a hill beside LMG's ear, and if it's a hill, where is it?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02/] It looks to me like a wall behind the gentleman with the boater, top of wall at his shoulder level, Tycor road would be just on the other side of the wall.  Those are low hills in the background and is about the view I would expect to see from this location before the houses were built across the road.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Which is to say, I think you're right, but the only hill I could see around Waterford on streetview was to the northwest.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02/] Its hard to tell from Google but there is a valley which runs south from Waterford towards Tramore, Tycor is on the North West side of this valley, the hills in the background are not very high more like high ground then anything else. The area known as kilbarry would be in the lower part of the valley and then further on on the otherside would be Killure/Ballinamona area.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I can't help with the location,  but I wonder if the persistent habit of putting a carpet on the lawn is to cover up a bald patch as a result of the Irish custom of putting the turf on the fire?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The quoins in the Original size make me think [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] has found it! Well done! OS 25" link.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The turf that you put on the fire is not a chunk of the lawn. Turf meaning lawn is a colloquialism. Turf is actually what decayed moss is before it becomes lignite. Besides, that's not a lawn - it's gravel.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley/] I will be back in Waterford in a couple of weeks, will have to take a closer look at this one.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia/] & [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02/]
 Besides, this is the "sunny" South East of Ireland, never any need to light a fire:)

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Waste of time reporting errors in the Census - those I reported three years ago still have not been corrected!

comment.author: 72163146@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Is there any point in reporting errors to the census? I reported an error when census first published and subsequently last year but it remains uncorrected to date. Not meaning to take away from the great service they provide.
